title: P86-1011

sentences.text: We examine the relationship between the two grammatical formalisms : Tree Adjoining Grammars and Head Grammars .
We briefly investigate the weak equivalence of the two formalisms .
We then turn to a discussion comparing the linguistic expressiveness of the two formalisms .

Entity-the_weak_equivalence_of_the_two_f.label: the weak equivalence of the two formalisms
aliases: the weak equivalence of the two formalisms
Entity-the_weak_equivalence_of_the_two_f.description: The relationship between Tree Adjoining Grammars and Head Grammars, characterized by similarities in their linguistic expressiveness but not necessarily identical in all aspects.

mentions.local_name: the weak equivalence of the two formalisms

Entity-a_discussion_comparing_the_lingui.label: a discussion comparing the linguistic expressiveness of the two formalisms
aliases: a discussion comparing the linguistic expressiveness of the two formalisms
Entity-a_discussion_comparing_the_lingui.description: A section in the paper P86-1011 where the authors compare and evaluate the expressive power of Tree Adjoining Grammars and Head Grammars.

mentions.local_name: a discussion comparing the linguistic expressiveness of the two formalisms

Entity-the_linguistic_expressiveness_of_.label: the linguistic expressiveness of the two formalisms
aliases: the linguistic expressiveness of the two formalisms
Entity-the_linguistic_expressiveness_of_.description: The ability of Tree Adjoining Grammars and Head Grammars to generate and describe natural language structures, measured by their capacity for expressing grammatical relationships and conveying meaning.

mentions.local_name: the linguistic expressiveness of the two formalisms

Entity-we_(1).label: We
Entity-we_(1).description: The authors examining the relationship between Tree Adjoining Grammars and Head Grammars

aliases: Tree Adjoining Grammars and Head Grammars
Entity-tree_adjoining_grammar.description: A linguistic theory that uses tree-like structures to represent sentences, allowing for efficient parsing and generation of syntactic structures.

mentions.local_name: Tree Adjoining Grammars and Head Grammars

aliases: the relationship between the two grammatical formalisms
Entity-the_relationship_between_the_two_.description: A connection or correspondence between two systems of grammar

Entity-head_grammar.label: Head Grammars
Entity-head_grammar.description: A linguistic theory or grammar that focuses on the structure of phrases, sentences, or clauses from a hierarchical perspective.

Entity-linguistic_expressiveness.label: linguistic expressiveness
Entity-linguistic_expressiveness.description: The ability or capacity for language to convey meaning, emotion, and thought in an effective manner.

Entity-formalism.label: formalisms
Entity-formalism.description: A set of mathematical rules or conventions used to describe a particular system, process, or concept.

summary: We examine the relationship between the two grammatical formalisms : Tree Adjoining Grammars and Head Grammars . We briefly investigate the weak equivalence of the two formalisms . We then turn to a discussion comparing the linguistic expressiveness of the two formalisms .

Predicate-and.label: and
Predicate-and.description: The predicate 'and' connects two entities or concepts to indicate a relationship of equivalence, similarity, or shared characteristics. It suggests that both subjects are related by some common property or category, forming a union or combination.

Predicate-examine.label: examine
Predicate-examine.description: To examine a predicate means to investigate or scrutinize its properties, characteristics, and relationships with other elements. It involves analyzing and evaluating the predicate's structure, function, and implications in order to gain a deeper understanding of its significance.

Predicate-investigate.label: investigate
Predicate-investigate.description: To investigate means to conduct a systematic and thorough examination or inquiry into something in order to gather information, understand its nature, or verify its validity. The subject of the investigation takes on an active role by engaging with the object, which can be a concept, phenomenon, theory, or problem, among others.

Predicate-discussing.label: discussing
Predicate-discussing.description: The predicate 'discussing' indicates that the subject (in this case, a discussion) is engaging with or exploring the object (the linguistic expressiveness of the two formalisms), often in an analytical or critical manner. This connection implies a thoughtful consideration and examination of the object's aspects, features, or implications.

Predicate-turn_to.label: turn to
Predicate-turn_to.description: To 'turn to' something means to shift one's attention or focus towards it. The subject of the predicate is redirecting their mental energy, interest, or effort towards the object, which can be an idea, a topic, a conversation, etc. This predicate implies a change in direction or orientation, as if the subject was previously focused on something else and now turns to consider or engage with the object.

skos:broader.label: has a broader term
skos:broader.description: The predicate 'has a broader term' indicates that the subject concept is a specific instance or subclass of a more general category or class represented by the object. It establishes a hierarchical relationship between the two, where the subject is a narrower or more specialized version of the object.
